awd_titl_txt: Structural Characterization of Protein and Protein Assemblies by Solid State NMR
awd_abstract_narration:
Structures inside living cells are often built from numerous copies of one protein. Like a brick wall made from many individual bricks, an oligomer can have size and strength unattainable by individual proteins. For example, during bacterial growth and division, a cell is pinched into two daughter cells by the action of a protein called FtsZ, many copies of which assemble into a ring that can constrict. In another example, when cells are stressed they respond by halting cellular activity. To do this they create a "mesh" of protein from many copies of TIA-1,  which stalls protein synthesis by trapping mRNA in the 
"mesh". Oligomeric structures can be exquisitely sensitive to events in the cell, much more than an individual protein could be, as illustrated by the classic example of oligomeric hemoglobin which is much more sensitive to oxygen than a single hemoglobin protein. Although oligomeric structures are crucially important, little is known about how the protein molecules pack together to form the larger structures. It is expected that knowledge of the oligomeric structures gained through this project will enhance our understanding of the biological role of these proteins in the cell.  This project will have broad impact through mentorship, teaching and outreach.  The investigator has a strong record of mentoring women in science and these efforts will continue.  Research activities will be showcased through outreach activities for middle and high school students.

Although our knowledge of protein structure has advanced considerably over the past 50 years, oligomeric proteins specifically have lagged behind, because they are difficult to study using traditional structural methods. This project pursues oligomeric structures through technical developments in solid state NMR, a promising new method that is well suited for determining structures of oligomeric proteins.  In these studies, the signal strength is enhanced through the use of low temperatures and by transfer of signal from electron spin to nuclear spin, in a method called Dynamic Nuclear Polarization. Optimization of sample freezing protocols, and multidimensional detection schemes pursued in this project are expected to improve the low temperature linewidths and enable the process of determining structures. Although most studies will be carried out with in vitro samples, additional methods are developed for elucidating structures within living cells.  The strategy for detection within the cell is to selectively enhance signals for the oligomeric protein of interest using a combination of selective isotopic enrichment and selective transfer of polarization from radicals tagged onto the protein of interest.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Knowledge of protein structures is important for rational discovery of new therapeutics and diagnostics, and for deep understanding of the principles of living systems. This information also enriches our broader understanding how complex flexible molecules can folded into ”self assembled” forms that can  adapt to their surrounding and also interact with other folded  molecules to create larger structures. Because proteins are optimized they can provide inspiring exemplars of molecular design for synthetic chemists making new materials.  While the tools for characterizing protein structures have advanced considerably and steadily since the dawn of this science (1950s), some important classes of proteins remain poorly characterized. We focused here on proteins that bind tightly to other copies of the same type of protein, aka “oligomeric” proteins. This class of proteins includes very important examples in terms of viability of life and opportunities for therapeutics and diagnostics. Traditional techniques are ill-suited for their characterization.  We develop new experimental approaches to characterizing these structures, methods which can be re-used for more examples in the future. The methods are variants of existing experimental nuclear magnetic resonance strategies and existing computer modelling strategies.

We also used our newly developed methods to study the structures a few prime examples of oligomeric proteins. One example is a collection of proteins that bind to each other in human cells, known as the necrosome, that controls whether cells harboring viral infections will be systematically removed. We show that the necrosome is an oligomer stack containing many alternating copies of two important drug binding proteins (RIPK3 and RIPK1), and that this stack broadly resembles amyloid plaques, for example as seen in Alzheimer's disease.  Another example is a protein found at high levels in bacterial cells. FtsZ forms fibers that help to give bacterial cells shape and viability and specifically facilitate cell division. The fibers are formed from many copies of this protein. We clarified the three-dimensional structure of the interface where two copies of FtsZ stick to one another. 

The studies have intellectual merit in that they reveal new knowledge and ideas regarding how proteins function in biological systems. Protein oligomeric plaques are well established in neurodegeneration, as hallmark diagnostics and likely causative agents. The suggestion that similar oligomeric forms also play normal protective roles in healthy cells is a new and potentially important idea and characterizing the relevant structures helps to explore this novel idea.  In the example of the bacterial system, the proteins (including oligomeric proteins) that help bacterial cells to grow and divide remain relatively understudied.  As prime examples of dynamic self assembly, they will doubtless illustrate novel and important aspects of the mechanisms of the molecules of life. 

We anticipate that possible broader impacts of this research will include the development of new therapeutic and diagnostic materials related to infections disease and other aspects of biomedicine.  Broader impacts also include the application of methods developed in this work or knowledge of these structures in the pursuit of information on other oligomeric proteins.  Finally a key broader impact is the training of several gifted Ph, D. students and undergraduate students who, as a result of their training, will be able to work in biomedicine at an expert level.
